Optimization problems, in which one wants to find the values of variables to maximize or minimize an objective function subject to constraints on which variables are allowed, are common throughout the physical and biological sciences, economics, finance and engineering. This course looks at the formulation of optimization problems as mathematical problems, characterizing solutions using necessary and/or sufficient optimality conditions and modern numerical methods and software for solving the problems. Both finite dimensional problems which involve a vector of variables, including linear and nonlinear programming, and infinite dimensional problems where the variables are functions, including optimal control problems, are covered.



This course is only available to students enrolled in the Master of Data Science, program 8646.

A 50-minute test run about 1/3 of the way through the course.

There will be short answer questions in which correct answers are sought and there will be some longer questions requiring clear and logical presentation of correct solutions as well as some simple proofs and verbal explanations.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a5d37494db3530d0be4672f5f3961908","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a5d37494db3530d0be4672f5f3961909","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"add37494db3530d0be4672f5f3961908","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"add37494db3530d0be4672f5f3961909","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"69d37494db3530d0be4672f5f396190b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"5","description":"

An assignment on solution methods of optimization problems and may involve modelling practical problems and writing a short report.

Assignments will give an opportunity for students to try their hand at more difficult problems requiring more than one line of argument and also introduce them to aspects of the subject which are not explicitly covered in lectures. The assignment will also require a student to draw together several topics in the course.

contentlets.description:
Optimization problems, in which one wants to find the values of variables to maximize or minimize an objective function subject to constraints on which variables are allowed, are common throughout the physical and biological sciences, economics, finance and engineering. This course looks at the formulation of optimization problems as mathematical problems, characterizing solutions using necessary and/or sufficient optimality conditions and modern numerical methods and software for solving the problems. Both finite dimensional problems which involve a vector of variables, including linear and nonlinear programming, and infinite dimensional problems where the variables are functions, including optimal control problems, are covered.


This course is only available to students enrolled in the Master of Data Science, program 8646.

of Science","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"ZZSC5806 - Regression Analysis for Data Scientists","description":"

Regression is a set of statistical techniques widely used to analyse relationships between several variables.


The topics covered in this course include: linear regression; weighted least squares; generalised linear models; tting GLMs and diagnostics; Poisson, binomial regression; analysis of variance; penalised regression methods; splines; penalised splines; thin plate splines; variable selection; generalised cross-validation; local likelihood; kernel smoothing; generalised additive models; multinomial logit analysis; ordinal logistic regression.


The lectures will be complemented with worked examples using the R data analysis and statistical programming software.



This online course is only available to students enrolled in the online Diploma of Data Science and the online Master of Data Science

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"6ae12cb1db106410be4672f5f3961946","name":"Fully online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Test","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

A two-hour exam covering the whole course but weighted towards the last half.

The final exam will mainly test students' mathematical understanding of the methods discussed in lectures, and they you can relate the output of statistical software to the theoretical formulas presented in the lectures.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"62e12cb1db106410be4672f5f3961947","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"62e12cb1db106410be4672f5f3961948","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"62e12cb1db106410be4672f5f3961949","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"62e12cb1db106410be4672f5f396194a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6ae12cb1db106410be4672f5f3961948","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"62e12cb1db106410be4672f5f396194d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Data Analysis Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"25","description":"

Assessment 3 extends learning through the application of knowledge and skills to various data analysis problems. Learners are given a series of data science problems throughout the course and present the outcomes of their detailed analysis in the form of a well-structured Rmarkdown report.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"62e12cb1db106410be4672f5f3961947","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"62e12cb1db106410be4672f5f3961948","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"62e12cb1db106410be4672f5f3961949","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"62e12cb1db106410be4672f5f396194a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6ae12cb1db106410be4672f5f3961948","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"6ae12cb1db106410be4672f5f3961949","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"72e12cb1db106410be4672f5f396195b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Introduction to Regression Analysis using R","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"5","description":"

Assessment 1 is an untimed multiple-choice and short answer test. Learners are provided with unlimited attempts; however, they must achieve a threshold of 80% to pass.

The test assesses learners’ understanding of what regression analysis is and the types of questions regression analysis can answer. It will also ensure learners’ basic proficiency with R and RStudio by asking them to run a basic linear regression analysis on a given data set and report outputs.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"62e12cb1db106410be4672f5f3961947","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"62e12cb1db106410be4672f5f3961948","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6ae12cb1db106410be4672f5f3961948","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7ee12cb1db106410be4672f5f3961962","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-Term Test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Assessment 2 is a timed 60-minute multiple-choice and short answer test, with a mathematical and computational component covering the first three weeks of the course: estimation methods, Generalised Linear Models (GLMs), the exponential family of distributions, Linear Gaussian Models (LGMs), Analysis of Variance (ANOVA), transformations, variable selection, cross validation, model assessment and selection, quality of fit and shrinkage methods.

Learners are provided with 1 attempt and must complete the test within 60 minutes—although they can do so at any point between the release and due dates. Learners are presented with minimum two specific problems (total of 20 questions), randomly selected from a problem/question bank; available problems/questions can be added to and amended with each delivery of the course.

of Engineering","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"ZZSC5836 - Data Mining and Machine Learning","description":"

Increasingly, organisations need to analyse enormous data sets to determine useful structure in them. In response to this, a range of statistical methods and tools have been developed in recent times to allow accurate and quick analysis of these sets. Machine learning is the algorithmic approach to learning from data. This course covers the key techniques in data mining technology, gives their theoretical background and shows their application.


Topics include: decision tree algorithms, regression and model tree algorithms, neural network learning, support vector machines, rule learning (such as association rules), lazy learning, version spaces, evaluating the performance of machine learning algorithms, Bayesian learning and model selection, algorithm-independent learning, ensemble learning, kernel methods, unsupervised learning (such as clustering) and inductive logic programming (relational learning).

contentlets.description:
The course gives a methodological background in Multivariate Analysis as a backbone of Applied Statistics. It introduces multivariate techniques including principal component analysis; canonical correlation analysis; cluster analysis; factor analysis and discriminant analysis. Computing and data analysis features prominently in this course.

This course is only available to students enrolled in the Graduate Diploma or Master of Data Science, programs 5646 and 8646 respectively.
contentlets.title: Multivariate Analysis for Data Scientists

This course provides an introduction to probability and distribution theory and introductory Statistical Inference. Students will learn the fundamental principles of inference: sufficiency, likelihoods, maximum likelihood and Bayesian methods.

contentlets.description:
This course provides an introduction to probability and distribution theory and introductory Statistical Inference. Students will learn the fundamental principles of inference: sufficiency, likelihoods, maximum likelihood and Bayesian methods. 

Estimation, confidence set construction and hypothesis testing and computationally intensive methods such as the bootstrap method are also discussed.

This course is only available to students enrolled in the postgraduate Data Science programs 7446, 5646, 8646.

Data Scientists","description":"

After describing the fundamentals of Bayesian inference, this course will examine the specification of prior and posterior distributions, Bayesian decision theoretic concepts, the ideas behind Bayesian hypothesis tests, model choice and model averaging, and evaluate the capabilities of several common model types, such as hierarchical and mixture models. An important part of Bayesian inference is the requirement to numerically evaluate complex integrals on a routine basis. Accordingly this course will also introduce the ideas behind Monte Carlo integration, importance sampling, rejection sampling, Markov chain Monte Carlo samplers such as the Gibbs sampler and the Metropolis-Hastings algorithm, and use of the WinBuGS posterior simulation software.

This course is only available to students enrolled in the Masters or Graduate Diploma of Data Science.

contentlets.description:
After describing the fundamentals of Bayesian inference, this course will examine the specification of prior and posterior distributions, Bayesian decision theoretic concepts, the ideas behind Bayesian hypothesis tests, model choice and model averaging, and evaluate the capabilities of several common model types, such as hierarchical and mixture models. An important part of Bayesian inference is the requirement to numerically evaluate complex integrals on a routine basis. Accordingly this course will also introduce the ideas behind Monte Carlo integration, importance sampling, rejection sampling, Markov chain Monte Carlo samplers such as the Gibbs sampler and the Metropolis-Hastings algorithm, and use of the WinBuGS posterior simulation software.

This course is only available to students enrolled in the Masters or Graduate Diploma of Data Science.
contentlets.title: Bayesian Inference and Computation for Data Scientists

This course covers the fundamentals of Data Science as it is applied in Computer Science, Economics and Mathematics and Statistics. The course will provide an introduction to topics such as databases, data analytics, data mining, Bayesian statistics, statistical software, econometrics, machine learning, business forecasting. The course also aims to indicate the relevance of the courses that follow in the program (including electives) and their place in data science and its applications.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f1e33c94db3530d0be4672f5f3961965","name":"Fully online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Assignment CSE","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Assignment questions taken from the CSE part of the course.

Due date:

Sunday 11:59pm, Week 3

Type:

Short answer questions

Length:

600 words or equivalent.

 

Submission

Questions 1 and 3 should be submitted as a PDF. Question 2 should be submitted as an .sql file.

Course learning outcomes

CLO3: Demonstrate proficiency in fundamental data science techniques and tools, including databases, data analytics, Bayesian statistics, statistical software, econometrics, business forecasting.

Purpose

This assessment task asks you to determine an appropriate data storage and management solution for two separate cases so that you become proficient in fundamental data science techniques such as drawing an ER diagram, creating a database and data analytics using statistical software such as MySQL.

Assessment instructions

Determine an appropriate data storage and management solution for two separate cases. In the first case you will be asked to draw an ER diagram to improve the management efficiency of a library management system. In the second case you will create a database using MySQL to answer various queries.

The questions for this assessment will be made available 12:00pm Thursday Week 3. You can access the questions via the Assessment link in Moodle.

For question 1 and question 3 save your answers as a PDF.

For question 2 save your answer as an .sql file.

Submit both files via the Assessment link in Moodle by 11:59pm of Sunday, Week 3.

Workload

You should spend about 1 hour on each question for this assessment.

Supporting activities

You should review the material presented in Week 2 to prepare for this assessment. In particular:

  • Topic 2.2 reading and questions on the Entity-Relationship model
  • Topic 2.3 SQL tutorials
  • Topic 2.5 cases study on data management

Supporting resources

To draw your ER diagram, you can use pen and paper and scan the drawing into a PDF or a (free) online whiteboard tool.

Feedback

Individual facilitator feedback will be available via the Course LMS website by Sunday Week 4. General feedback can also be provided to the entire class via an announcement or discussion forum.

Marking criteria

Marks are allocated for each question for a total of 15 marks. This mark will be scaled to 20% for the assessment overall. You will need to get the correct answer and to show steps where indicated for each question.

The breakdown of marks for each question is:

Question 1 – 4 marks
Question 2 – 7 marks
Question 3 – 4 marks

There will be a final exam with three sections on different topic areas from Econ, CSE and Maths. Practice questions will be made available to students.

Due date: October 15, Week 7 (starting time to be released).

Type: Online examination.

Length: 3 hours.

 

Submission: The exam will be a fully online, remotely invigilated exam. You will access and submit your exam using Moodle.

Learning outcomes:

CLO1: Demonstrate an understanding and appreciation of the relevance of the data sciences in the modern world.

CLO2: Apply mathematical and computational techniques, and business sensibilities, to real-world problems.

CLO3: Demonstrate proficiency in fundamental data science techniques and tools, including databases, data analytics, Bayesian statistics, statistical software, econometrics, business forecasting.

Purpose: The final exam allows you to demonstrate your proficiency in data science techniques and understanding of key concepts presented throughout the course. It gives you an opportunity to demonstrate your breadth of knowledge across all aspects of the course and to ensure that you have the foundational skills and understanding required to continue your studies in the Master of Data Science program.

Overview: The final exam will assess students’ knowledge of materials covered in the?course as a whole.?It?will be a remotely invigilated, fully online exam that runs for three hours?under full exam conditions.

Assessment Instructions:The main exam will be held on October 15th at 10am AEST.

A supplementary exam will be held a week later for those who have legitimate reasons for missing the first exam.

You should have been issued with the device requirements to sit the exam. See Supporting Resources below if you do not have this document. You only need to fill these requirements for the exam but you are advised to have them prepared in advance and use the equipment during the course to practice.

If you are concerned about your internet connection for completing the exam, you can/should check with your workplace (if appropriate) to see if you can do the exam there in a suitable spot.

You can expect to answer questions that ask you to provide short answers, do free drawing and annotate a drawing.

The exam will be remotely invigilated by a provider such as Examity. There will be a human invigilator to enforce a series of exam conditions. You will be monitored via webcam and screen-share. Your entire exam session will be recorded and stored on UNSW infrastructure afterwards for a minimum of 7 years.

Workload: Your workload to prepare for the exam will depend on how you have engaged with the activities presented throughout the course and the assessments to-date.

Supporting activities:You will be given an opportunity to practice for the exam in Week X through a practice quiz. This quiz will not count towards your assessment. We recommend you have the technical environment recommended prepared for this quiz to test its performance and to foreshadow any issues that might arise under exam conditions.

As the exam covers key concepts and skills presented throughout the course, you should review material from all weeks in preparation for this assessment.

Supporting resources: Device requirements are provided in the Course Outline.

Feedback:Results will be released when finalised.

Assessment criteria: Available with the examination..

Assignment questions taken from the maths part of the course.

 

Due date:

11:59pm Sunday, Week 5.

Type:

Short answer questions.

Length:

600 words or equivalent

 

Submission

Both questions 1 and 2 should be submitted in a single PDF document via the Assessment link in Moodle.

Course Learning Outcomes

CLO2: Apply mathematical and computational techniques, and business sensibilities, to real-world problems

CLO3: Demonstrate proficiency in fundamental data science techniques and tools, including databases, data analytics, Bayesian statistics, statistical software, econometrics, business forecasting

Purpose

The purpose of this assessment is to analyse two separate data sets to investigate business problems so that you can demonstrate proficiency in fundamental data science techniques and tools and the application of mathematical and computational techniques, and business sensibilities, to real-world problems.

Overview

This assessment task requires you to analyse two separate data sets to investigate business problems. In the first case you will be given a data set to produce a model for prediction. You will need to produce a scatter plot of the data and analyse the data to answer a range of questions. In the second case you will be investigating tax fraud using tree-based methods.

Assessment instructions

The questions for this assessment will be made available 12:00pm Thursday Week 5. You can access the questions via the Assessment link in Moodle.

Your answers for both questions 1 and 2 should be saved into the one PDF document. If you are drawing the tree-diagram by hand for question 2, you will need to scan it into the PDF document.

Submit your answers via the Assessment link in Moodle by 11:59pm of Sunday, Week 5.

Workload

You should spend about 3 hours in total to answer both question 1 and 2.

Supporting activities

You should review the material presented in Weeks 4 and 5 to prepare for this assessment. In particular:

  • Topic 4.1 simple regression
  • Topic 4.2 multiple regression
  • Topic 5.2 regression trees
  • Topic 5.3 classification trees

Supporting resources

You will need the Excel spreadsheet ELECTRIC.xls to answer question 1. This will be provided with the questions, Thursday Week 5.

Feedback

Individual feedback from your Online Lecturer will be available via the Course LMS website by Sunday Week 6. General feedback can also be provided to the entire class via an announcement or discussion forum.

Marking criteria

Marks are allocated for each question for a total of 30 marks. This mark will be scaled to 20% for the assessment overall. You will need to get the correct answer and to show steps where indicated for each question.

The breakdown of marks for each question is:

Question 1 – 15 marks
Question 2 – 15 marks

Assignment questions taken from the business part of the course.

  • Due date:

    Part A: Sunday 11:59pm, Week 1.
    Part B: Sunday 11:59pm, Week 2.

    Type:

    Report/Peer feedback

    Length:

    500 words

     

    Submission

    This is a written assessment and will be submitted as either a Word or PDF document to the Moodle Workshop tool for peer assessment.

    Learning outcomes

    CLO1: Demonstrate an understanding and appreciation of the relevance of the data sciences in the modern world.

    Course Learning Outcomes

    The purpose of this assessment task is to explore the role of data and data scientists within an organisation or industry of your choice and to write a short report. This will contribute to you achieving course learning outcome 1 ‘Demonstrate an understanding and appreciation of the relevance of the data sciences in the modern world.’

    Assessment instructions

    Part A:

    You are asked to choose an industry or organisation in which you currently work, have previously worked or that is familiar to you.??Your task is to explore the role of data and data scientists within this organisation or industry and to write a short report of no more than 500 words on your findings.

    You should consider the needs of the organisation and the type and scale of data currently in use. You should explain how it is being analysed, by whom and how the resulting information is put to use.?Be mindful of commercial confidentiality issues in writing the report. It is not advisable to name your company.??

    Part B:

    Provide timely constructive feedback on the work of three (3) peers, using the marking criteria provided.?See the following instructions:?

    Peer review instructions

    To complete this assessment, you will review the work of three of your peers using the rubric provided. You will receive two marks for your assessment:?

    • One mark for your submission (calculated as the weighted mean of the marks given by your peers). This is called your ‘Grade for submission’ and will be marked out of 100 then weighted to 7%.?
    • One mark for the quality of your peer marking (calculated on how close your marking is to the mean for the submission). This is called your ‘Grade for assessment’ and will be calculated out of 100 and then weighted to 3%.?

    Submission guidelines

    You will be submitting using the Moodle Workshop tool. The workshop is divided into four phases:?

    Phase 1: Submission phase

    Submit your assessment as a Word or PDF document by the due date.??

    Phase 2: Assessment phase

    You will be randomly allocated three other assessments to review. The submissions will be listed under?Assigned submissions to assess?once the submission deadline has passed. You will only be able to review your peers’ work when you have submitted your own assessment.?

    Click the ‘Assess’ button. This will take you to a new page. Click on the file to retrieve the paper that has been assigned to you and assign marks according to the rubric marking guide. You can copy and paste the descriptor from each criterion level into the comments field as shown below:

     

     

    Write a comment on the report?as a whole in?the ‘Overall feedback’ section of the assessment form.?

    Remember to save your response. You may re-assess the paper up until the deadline. To do this, click on the?‘Re-assess’ button.?

    Phase 3: Grading evaluation phase

    During this phase of the Workshop your Online Lecturer will check that your submission has been reviewed fairly and will finalise the marks for your submission and the quality of your peer marking (grade for assessment). You will not be able to modify your submission or peer marking during this phase.?

    Phase 4: Close phase?

    During this phase, the final grades calculated in the previous phase are pushed into the course?Gradebook. This will result in the Workshop grades appearing in the Gradebook and in the Workshop. You will be able to view your submission, and your submission assessments.?

    In the gradebook you will see two marks for the assessment (submission and assessment) weighted to 7% and 3%:?

     

    Workload

    The total suggested time for this assessment:??

    • Writing report: 3?hrs
    • Peer marking: 1?hr

    Supporting activities

    In summary, the following activities are relevant to developing your report:

    • Experiments in a big data world Week 1
    • Case study Indian Aadhaar database

    Supporting resources

    Click here for more information on the Moodle Workshop tool.

    Feedback

    You will receive feedback from three (3) of your peers by Monday?in?Week 2. Your Online Lecturer will monitor the peer review process and provide feedback if required.?General feedback can also be provided to the entire class via an announcement or discussion forum.???

    Marking criteria

    Part A (7/10)

    You will be assessed according to the marking criteria in the table below.

    Part B (3/10):

    Completion of three (3) peer reviews by Sunday 11:59pm in Week 2.

    MARKING CRITERIAGREATLY BELOW EXPECTATIONS 0-4SLIGHTLY BELOW EXPECTATIONS 5-9MEETS EXPECTATIONS 10-14GREATLY EXCEEDS EXPECTATIONS 15-20DESCRIPTION OF THE DATA NEEDS OF THE ORGANISATION 20%The organisation’s data needs are very poorly explained.The organisation’s data needs are explained but without sufficient detail.The organisation’s data needs are explained well.The organisation’s data needs are explained very coherently and original thought is shown.DESCRIPTION OF THE TYPE AND SCALE OF DATA IN USE 20%The description of both the data type and scale is very superficial or non-existent.Some improvements are needed in the description of the data type or scale.There is a good description of both the data type and scale.There is a very well- considered and detailed description of both the data type and scale.EXPLANATION OF THE DATA ANALYSIS METHOD 20%There is a very poor explanation of the method of data analysis.The data analysis method is explained but without sufficient detail.The data analysis method is well explained.The data analysis method is very clearly and coherently explained.EXPLANATION OF WHO IS ANALYSING THE DATA 20%There is minimal or no evidence given of who is analysing the data.There is insufficient evidence given about who is analysing the data.Good evidence is presented about who is analysing the data.Excellent description is given of who is analysing the data.DESCRIPTION OF HOW THE ANALYSIS RESULTS ARE USED 20%The description of how the results are used is very superficial or non-existent.The uses of the results are explained but without sufficient detail.The uses of the results are explained well.The uses of the results are explained very thoughtfully and coherently.

contentlets.description: This course covers the fundamentals of Data Science as it is applied in Computer Science, Economics and Mathematics and Statistics. The course will provide an introduction to topics such as databases, data analytics, data mining, Bayesian statistics, statistical software, econometrics, machine learning, business forecasting. The course also aims to indicate the relevance of the courses that follow in the program (including electives) and their place in data science and its applications.
contentlets.title: Foundations of Data Science

This course exposes students to research methods in applying data science techniques to a research project. The course serves as a capstone in the Master of Data Science program. Students will be required to apply and demonstrate their learning from the courses in the program. It also requires students to present their work in visual and verbal forms including a presentation.
